summary.primary_finding: Chattering degradation inversely correlates with IC magnitude
summary.hypothesis: Mode confusion: Small IC causes rapid scheduler switching, large IC causes consistent conservative mode

ic_0.05.note: Counterintuitive: conservative gains should reduce effort

ic_0.30.interpretation: High baseline variability, adaptive increases by 18%

chattering_vs_ic_magnitude.interpretation: Very strong negative correlation: larger IC → smaller chattering increase

control_effort_vs_ic_magnitude.interpretation: Nearly perfect negative correlation: larger IC → smaller effort increase

chattering_vs_control_effort.interpretation: Nearly perfect positive correlation: more chattering → more effort
chattering_vs_control_effort.note: System fighting against chattering increases control usage

ic_0.05_behavior.likely_trajectory: Rapid oscillation between aggressive/transition as |θ| crosses 0.1 rad threshold
ic_0.05_behavior.hypothesis: Mode confusion: Hybrid k1/k2 cannot adapt fast enough (gamma1=0.5)

ic_0.30_behavior.likely_trajectory: Stays in conservative mode for 1-3 seconds as system settles
ic_0.30_behavior.hypothesis: Stable conservative mode: Hybrid adapts slowly but consistently

scheduler_mode_inference.key_difference: Small IC causes UNSTABLE scheduling (rapid mode switching), large IC causes STABLE scheduling (consistent conservative mode). Hybrid's slow k1/k2 adaptation (gamma1=0.5) cannot track rapid mode changes.

hypothesis_1_gain_interference.evidence: Control effort INCREASES (+69%) despite conservative gains
hypothesis_1_gain_interference.mechanism: Reduced c1/c2 → smaller |s| → slower k1/k2 → insufficient control → more effort needed

hypothesis_2_mode_confusion.evidence: Degradation severity inversely correlates with IC magnitude
hypothesis_2_mode_confusion.mechanism: Small IC → rapid scheduler switching near 0.1 rad threshold → k1/k2 instability

hypothesis_3_feedback_instability.evidence: Chattering std increases with adaptive scheduling (0.108 → 0.405 at ±0.05)
hypothesis_3_feedback_instability.mechanism: Positive feedback: chattering → large |θ| → conservative gains → worse chattering
hypothesis_3_feedback_instability.confidence: MEDIUM - variance data supports, needs |s| trajectory analysis

finding_1_control_effort_paradox.observation: Conservative gains (50% reduction) INCREASE control effort by 69%
finding_1_control_effort_paradox.expected: Reduced gains should reduce control usage
finding_1_control_effort_paradox.explanation: System compensates for insufficient k1/k2 by saturating actuator more frequently
finding_1_control_effort_paradox.implication: Scheduler defeats its own purpose for Hybrid controller

finding_2_variance_explosion.interpretation: Adaptive scheduling introduces massive performance variability
finding_2_variance_explosion.implication: Unpredictable behavior - some trials have moderate chattering, others catastrophic

finding_3_overshoot_consistency.observation: Overshoot increases ~13% uniformly across all IC magnitudes
finding_3_overshoot_consistency.interpretation: Conservative gains uniformly reduce damping, independent of mode switching frequency
finding_3_overshoot_consistency.implication: Overshoot penalty is fundamental, not mode-confusion related

classical_trend.consistency: Uniform benefit across all IC magnitudes

comparison_with_classical_smc.root_cause_difference: Classical has NO internal adaptation (fixed K/K_d), so scheduler effects are immediate and consistent. Hybrid has SLOW internal adaptation (k1/k2), creating mode mismatch and instability.

chattering_degradation_formula.note: Formula suggests crossover point at IC=0.33 rad where adaptive scheduling might help

priority_1_mode_confusion.test: Phase 2.2 - Log scheduler mode switches vs k1/k2 freeze events
priority_1_mode_confusion.expected: High mode switch frequency (10-50 Hz) at small IC, low (1-5 Hz) at large IC
priority_1_mode_confusion.validation: If confirmed, explains trend reversal completely

priority_2_gain_interference.test: Phase 2.1 - Manual 50% c1/c2 scaling, measure k1(t)/k2(t) trajectories
priority_2_gain_interference.expected: k1/k2 reach 60-70% of baseline values, correlate with +69% control effort
priority_2_gain_interference.validation: If confirmed, proves superlinear feedback mechanism

priority_3_sliding_surface_dynamics.validation: If confirmed, demonstrates feedback loop instability

immediate: DO NOT deploy adaptive scheduling for Hybrid controller
phase_3_investigation: Test selective c1/c2 scheduling (keep λ1/λ2 fixed)
Test selective λ1/λ2 scheduling (keep c1/c2 fixed)
Hypothesis: One subset may be schedulable without breaking k1/k2 adaptation
phase_4_enhancement: If Phase 3 shows promise, develop |s|-based thresholds (not |θ|)
Implement slower switching (0.05 rad hysteresis vs 0.01 rad)
Add dynamic adaptation rate compensation (boost gamma1/gamma2 when c1/c2 reduced)
